reasoning:
Essay A presents a more robust and scientifically rigorous exploration. Its research question is well-contextualized within a complex, real-world issue of fuel efficiency and environmental impact. The strength of Essay A lies in its meticulous handling of variables; the controlled variables are presented in a clear table with detailed justifications for why each variable matters and precisely how it will be controlled. For instance, controlling the "Source of E10" by purchasing it all "off of the same gas station in the same purchase" demonstrates a high level of forethought regarding the consistency of the starting materials. Furthermore, the justification for choosing kJ/g over kJ/mol as the unit for the dependent variable shows a sophisticated understanding of the chemical realities of commercial fuel mixtures.

Essay B, while demonstrating good personal engagement and a very thorough safety assessment that references specific standards (CLEAPPS), has a significant weakness in its experimental design. The attempt to control the surface area of the MnO₂ catalyst by grinding it "using 200 turns at medium pressure" is a major methodological flaw. This method is not reproducible or reliable and introduces a significant uncontrolled variable that directly impacts the rate of reaction. While the student identifies the variable, the method of control is weak. In contrast, Essay A’s controlled variables are more realistically and effectively managed. Therefore, due to its superior experimental design and more rigorous control of variables, Essay A demonstrates a higher quality of exploration.
